Posts.Title: March 2017 Surgery plantchild Molly50

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2017 10:49PM Kayla250 wrote: I'm so sorry you find yourself with us. It sounds like you have been through a lot lately. I, being from Canada, am amazed as to how quickly you will be getting your results. But regardless as to how quick, there is still a period of not knowing. It is especially hard when all we know is that there are concerns. Most "concerns" are because of benign causes. The description does sound like a lymph node and an enlarged lymph node. Lymph nodes do swell when fighting off infection or injury. Please keep us posted. Hoping for a benign outcome
Posts.Title: Please help to reduce this tension EbeyR Kayla250

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2017 05:56PM Kayla250 wrote: Being reassured from two women, who are in the medical field, should be taken as a positive mindset. Out of curiosity, are you pregnant? Midwife? But with that said. Only making an appointment (a wait) having a mammogram (a wait), probably being sent for an ultrasound because dense breast don't mammogram well (a wait) and then if anything is questionable (another wait) being referred for the appropriate procedure.....et As you see, there is a lot of waiting and wondering and anxiety; I agree with MinusTwo, you may need anti-anxiety meds. But by-all-means, start with your first appointment and don't stop until you are comfortable with the diagnoses. Here's hoping for a benign outcome!
Posts.Title: Indentation-24 yrs. old sunshineplz MTwoman

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2017 12:26PM Kayla250 wrote: Sorry to hear you're having to enter the waiting game. I don't think any one answer will reassure you that you have nothing to worry about. The very moment you noticed a change in your breast gave you the ok to worry, so be easy on yourself over that. It would be interesting to see where, on the BiRAD, scale the radiologist put your US? Having the two different doctors on your case is a benefit to you. Doctor's are really expected to err on the side of caution; really the "Rule out" rule. That is to say, I believe your boob doc is trying to satisfy this...to refer you to procedures that will definitively "rule out" cancer and once that's is done you will be able to relax. It is the waiting that is the worst part of the whole process. I am glad that you were able to have done, what was done for you, so quickly. Hopefully being here (forum) will make you feel like you're not alone in this.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2017 10:27AM Kayla250 wrote: I hope it turns out to be nothing. I never had symptoms such as those, my symptom was only a lump, no pain, no other symptom, just the lump. My mother had had a couple of lumps aspirated a couple of different times in her life and they were nothing, so I thought I had that same thing. But mine was cancer. It is definitely important to see a doctor, we are all very different (even between mother and daughter) and only a doctor can make the diagnose. Good luck
Posts.Title: Questions SnoodleBug Kayla250

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2017 08:07AM Kayla250 wrote: I think it is great that you were able to get it removed so quickly, I really don't believe that would be possible in my neck-of-the-woods. But I would think that because you had, what sounds like to be, an open biopsy, the tissue would be sent to the pathologist for analysis. A surgeon would not be able to tell if individual cells are malignant or not. I hope you get those results soon. I had my biopsy last Friday and don't expect the results until about Tuesday next week (a week to 10 days). Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: Help Please Amanda702 MTwoman

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2019 05:31PM Kayla250 wrote: Good afternoon all, I'm sorry lisbet and Michelle, you too are experiencing the unknown. I find myself trying to find the same answers. I have been reading everything, almost everything 😊, And am so glad there are so many so knowledgeable of txs . I have know clue what is happening. I was told that my liver mets are inoperable and that even a biopsy was too risky because my tumours are next to the heptic vein and that the liver doesn't take radiation well. I started I/L end of November and a baseline CT Dec 6, I had my new CT last week. The biggest tumour grew from 3.5cm to 6.4cm and there are many new smaller growths. I wonder if anyone might know what the next step might be, my appointment is on Wednesday. I have never heard of Y90 and don't know if it's available here? Am I right in assuming because treatment didn't work, and they are growing so fast, the mets must no longer be er+ HER2- I feel so uneducated and don't know what I should expect, ask or need...this is only first line, could it possibly be my last

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2017 08:31PM Kayla250 wrote: I'm not sure if another mammogram is needed after the ultrasound. I guess it might be to take a closer look or a diagnostic one. I am awaiting a biopsy to rule out a recurrence. My series of events was: 1.routine mammogram, 2. lump found, 3. immediately a second magnified mammogram, then 4. immediately to the radiologist who 5. immediately sent me for ultrasound. 6.A couple of days later my doctor called me with those results and a biopsy will be preformed by my surgeon. That consult appointment is next week. I think you're at the awaiting ultrasound stage; my first time around a needle biopsy was performed during the ultrasound. So hopefully if it is needed a biopsy will be done there for you too. Waiting is very hard...

But Y90 still seems to be some new...I’ll definitely ask Thank you HLB, I will research about abraxane too. It sure sounds promising. I truly hope that everyone going thru progression finds their perfect treatment this week.
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2019 05:33PM Kayla250 wrote: HolyHope, I am so sorry that your mother's liver mets are advancing, I do not have any answers and hope some one can respond to your question. Without taking anything away from your question, I am having advancement as well...but I have been on Ibrance since November. Which leads me to my update. Up here in Canada, I don't live in a major centre so on a month by month basis, we see a GP with special education in supporting an MO in satellite communities. My appointment today was with this GPO. He showed me my CT of the liver mets and I am still in a little shock how big the largest tumour looks...6.5cm, I can't imagine how those that have had liver tumours as big as 20 must look. It is in Segment 4a there are 6 other smaller throughout the liver. He cannot give me definitive answers as to the next step but Ibrance is now stopped, I remain on Letrozole. I see the actual MO next Monday. I will ask about a possible biopsy then...I am pretty sure Y90 is not available, but I will ask that as well. I thank everyone for their support, wow this is a crazy ride.

Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2019 12:23PM Kayla250 wrote: Good morning, it still is here on the west coast ;) SandiBeach-I had originally been told that even a biopsy could not be done, too close to heptic vein. This last appointment, I asked about the option of a biopsy, and yes but as we discussed it, it became very clear that it would need to be done prior to starting second line (Xeloda) and that would delay starting to May. As the rate of growth is shocking to me, I didn’t want to wait. I still don’t think y90 is available here. I will ask when i get Rx filled but I would assume it would have mentioned by now. I am hoping X will do the trick and stop progression and I will more comfortable asking about other treatments. WIshing you all a great rest of the day
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2019 11:17PM Kayla250 wrote: Bornfighter-my largest tumour is at the top of 4a segment of liver...it is hitting the diaphragm, easily seen on CT and I experience pain that can get unbearable at times. I have an at home breakthrough pain management process that an er doc gave my pcp, it involves pain meds and rx anti-inflammatory. If this process doesn’t relieve the pain I’m to go to the er for IV pain meds (I haven’t been to ER since January). Also, because I get nauseous too I have rx for an acid reducer and use peptobismol. Relaxation techniques and rest. Hopefully that helps you. I am awaiting a new protocol (Xedola) to start April 10th and hoping it stops the progression I’m experiencing as the tumour seems to be stretching the capsule and hitting the diaphragm more and more these days

Good night and a peaceful sleep to all.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2017 06:12AM Kayla250 wrote: I agree Lily55, an ultrasound, it would definitely verify if the lump is fluid filled or solid mass. Posts.Title: New to forum gathering information and being well informed. Faithoftheheart Kayla250

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2019 01:40PM Kayla250 wrote: Hi, just noticed this question, but a little dry blood is fine, I use to use some rubbing alcohol to clean around everything exposed to air and touch, ever so gently of course. I assume you had mastectomy without reconstruction but be assured that swelling is a huge factor in the beginning and actually stays around for an extremely long time, it is frustrating but over time it does resolve. However, even though I had a plastic surgeon, I was surprised how much fat I had under there but unlike you I have a bra to mask it. I’m in Canada and had reconstruction and our health care covers Revision surgery that is needed afterward, but I can’t say if it would be would be covered where you may live.
